Inflation is above the target 2% rate, and so Tapering will begin after the November 3rd FOMC meeting.  Fed chairman Powell signaled this in his September press conference. October 5th edit to add more detail:
The Fed's purchases of longer-term bonds (quantitative easing) will taper down gradually. The expectation is it will take 6 months to get to zero purchases. This is called the Taper.  The Fed raising short term interest rates is called Liftoff.  Powell expects Liftoff to be after the Taper is complete.  The Fed set 2 Taper framework tests, and these both have mostly been met: inflation is well above target and unemployment is approaching maximum. Inflation is high because of supply chain disruptions, and this will push the Fed to taper its bond purchases. The Fed needs to have Liftoff available to fight possible inflation. The title of this question does not match up with their explanation, because the title speaks about bond purchases and then later they clarify it also means mortgage-backed securities. I don't expect them to reduce bond purchases, really ever. There is no market for US debt anymore. The Federal Reserve has purchased more than 100% of newly issued treasuries for about the last 2 years. The US government is issuing continued increasing amounts of debt with all of their off budget emergency spending and I don't see this stopping. Someone has to buy the debt, and the only real purchaser is the Federal Reserve. China, russia, etc are slowly trying to sell off their holdings. Most others only buy US debt knowing that the FED will always be there to buy it up in the secondary market. And US government cannot afford to pay a market rate of interest on the debt so they have to keep the interest rate artificially low.  I do see a possibility that they reduce mortgage purchases. Of course, if they do, mortgage rates rise and the music stops. Housing prices fall which leads to decreased spending. I think they know this but they're trapped.  Another factor is that 3.5% of mortgages are currently in the covid forbearance program which is about to come to an end. If even a fraction of those end up going on the market or foreclosing that could be a major blow to the housing market. And the housing market fuels the stock market.  They will reduce mortgage purchases long before they raise the federal funds rate. I still think they understand it means the end... If bad news comes out like a bad jobs report it usually means that the markets go up because people interpret it to mean a better chance that the FED will continue stimulus. In other words, the markets are more concerned with whether the FED is going to continue easy money then they are concerned with actual fundamentals. This shows how artificial the economy is right now. I really think keeping asset prices inflated and keeping the stock market going is more important to the FED than reining in inflation, especially since they really can't rein in inflation. Reducing quantitative easing is not going to stop inflation, and raising the federal funds rate by 1% is not going to stop inflation. Even a 3% federal funds rate is still extremely low, and that would annihilate the market.

I think it's still 50%.  Reason is they will be leery of upsetting the financial community.  I do believe they will anounce that they will be doing it by Dec 16.  If it happens, it will be very small amounts to start.
